snippet: Two United States-financed nonprofit groups paid about $4 million in bail to fly 11 employees out of reach of Egyptian courts.
abstract: Two United States-financed nonprofit groups paid about $4 million in bail to fly 11 employees out of reach of Egyptian courts in a deal that capped weeks of bruising diplomatic wrangling and set off a new outpouring of anti-American denunciations; no Egyptian official has accepted responsibility for the release; instead, judges and prosecutors have distanced themselves from the decision and traded accusations of political capitulation and conflict of interest.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and STEVEN LEE MYERS
byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo, and Steven Lee Myers from Washington. Mayy El Sheikh contributed reporting from Cairo.

lead_paragraph: Two United States-financed nonprofit groups paid about $4 million in bail to fly 11 employees out of reach of Egyptian courts.

headline.main: U.S. Defendants Leave Egypt Amid Growing Backlash
headline.print_headline: U.S. Defendants Leave Egypt Amid Acrimony
